title: Will a Boeing Starliner spacecraft dock with the International Space Station (ISS) before 1 July 2021?
preds: There are no Starliner flights scheduled before 1 July 2021.
Re-forecasting down to 0% with only one week remaining.
No way.  If it was going to happen it would be announced at this point.  Boeing is going to surprise us and announce it 10 days ahead of time?  I put 1%.  It's very unlikely.  Never put 0% though.
They should repeat this question,  with a 2022 date, then it might get a 50/50 chance.

No—  From:
https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/04/it-now-seems-likely-that-starliner-will-not-launch-crew-until-early-2022/ “...there will be no docking ports available this summer until about July 20, the approximate date when the CRS-22 Dragon will depart the station and return to Earth. This departure will open an approximately one-month window during which Starliner could make its test flight. Therefore, although NASA and Boeing have not yet made a target date public, we can expect this flight to take place no earlier than late July or early August [of 2021]

Well, more news! As of yesterday, the next two ULA Atlas V rocket launches scheduled (both from the same launchpad, SLC-41) were STP-3 for June 23rd, and OFT-2 (the Starliner launch) for July 30th. But it was just announced today that STP-3 is going to be delayed ( https://twitter.com/ulalaunch/status/1400800541198934017 ). Now, the announced technical reasons for the STP-3 delay do not directly apply to OFT-2, so there's no specific reason to expect this to change the announced OFT-2 schedule. However, there are still two issues to consider: 1) Does the delay eliminate any chance of OFT-2 being moved up, given the pad will likely be used for STP-3 later in June or in early July? Or, conversely, if STP-3 is delayed enough, might OFT-2 actually get put on the pad and launch earlier than previously planned, possibly even in June? 2) Is the technical reason truly unique to the STP-3 configuration, or does it reveal a deeper flaw in Atlas V that would affect OFT-2? Now, my answers are "There wasn't any chance of moving up before July 1st anyway, and this doesn't change that either way" and "It's probably unique". My probability is staying, well, where it was on the day this question opened. But you might find that the STP-3 delay affects what you expect.

So, highly unlikely that anything will happen before July 30. The mission is also not even mentioned currently in NASA Launches and Landings schedule [2]. NASA has dropped the crewed Starliner test mission to ISS from the official schedule ( https://www.nasa.gov/launchschedule/ ), and still has not relisted the uncrewed test mission (the mission this question would resolve on).  On the other hand, it has gone ahead and listed both the Northrop Grumman commercial resupply mission (July) and the next SpaceX commercial crew mission (October 23, 2021) to ISS.

https://bgr.com/science/starliner-delay-boeing-nasa-5910213/ The Starliner program has been an absolute disaster in so many ways that it’s actually painful to remember that NASA dumped $4.2 billion of taxpayer money on Boeing to build the spacecraft. It has seen delay after delay, and once the vehicle was finally ready to travel to space on its uncrewed test mission, the spacecraft glitched out, burned a bunch of fuel it wasn’t supposed to burn and had to come back to Earth without ever making it to the orbiting laboratory.

Given the current schedule it appears there won't be an open docking port until July 20 if the next two launches go as planned. https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/04/it-now-seems-likely-that-starliner-will-not-launch-crew-until-early-2022/

So, the latest news available is that, while the Boeing craft is on the verge of being technically ready for launch, the next time the ISS will have an open docking port for the unmanned test flight is late July ( https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/04/it-now-seems-likely-that-starliner-will-not-launch-crew-until-early-2022/ ). That'll delay the crew launch until 2022 probably, since they'll need months after July to analyze the data even if it goes off without a hitch (thus the date/headline in the link). I'm still a little skeptical about it being ready, because I'd think there would have been an official NASA "NET July" announced already if that were true, but either way that puts the launch after the question deadline.

NASA still doesn't have a date listed ( https://www.nasa.gov/launchschedule/ ), but SpaceflightNow is now saying late July ( https://spaceflightnow.com/launch-schedule/ ). Presumably the latter is based on inside informants. I'm personally feeling very vindicated in my early skepticism right now, having been at 0% since the opening day of the question. My feeling had been that if the "set the program back about two weeks" claim in the March 4 NASA blog post ( https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/2021/03/04/nasa-and-boeing-evaluating-launch-date-for-orbital-flight-test-2/ ) were accurate, they would have immediately announced a May date at the same time. After all, if the program's readiness is really delayed by only two weeks, but the next launch is a month later, you can confidently declare that the program will be ready for launch. So I decided there was some serious issues going on which were being minimized and chose to start at 0%, with the statement "When and if they announce a launch date before 1 July, I'll consider the odds that they'll be able to meet it." Well, when and if they announce a launch date before 1 July, I'll consider the odds that they'll be able to meet it. Until then, I'm sticking with 0%.
The most recent (3/31/21) launch schedule designation for Starliner's second flight test is "no earlier than late July": https://spaceflightnow.com/launch-schedule/

FWIW, the linked source seems to indicate at least a possibility that the Starliner's next launch may get moved beyond May. Ref. the July launches section (below): Starliner's date is still 'TBD' but the recently updated entry's text states: "...Delayed from Jan. 4. Moved forward from March 29, April 2 and May." https://spaceflightnow.com/launch-schedule/

According to a Nasa blog , "Based on the current traffic at the space station, NASA does not anticipate that OFT-2 can be accomplished later in April. NASA and Boeing are working to find the earliest possible launch date." (https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/2021/03/04/nasa-and-boeing-evaluating-launch-date-for-orbital-flight-test-2/). Which would still leave launch windows in both May and June. There seems to be a desire from both Nasa and Boeing for the launch to happen so I will initiate at 70% given the tight window, and I will assume an 88% success rate of docking, given they have already gone through OFT-1 (note, I have no decent base rate to go on, so those probabilities are mostly guesswork).

Although third parties (like Spaceflight Now) list the launch as May, the public NASA site (https://www.nasa.gov/launchschedule/) still doesn't list it at all. If and when NASA lists it with a date earlier than July 1st, I will revise my probability upward -- sharply upward. But as long as NASA isn't willing to give it even a "no earlier than" date, my analysis remains that whatever the actual problem was that caused the cancellation of the planned launch is unresolved. Yes, NASA said back on March 4th that events had "set the program back about two weeks." Based on that and the fact that April slots to deal with ISS are reserved for other things, a NET May date would be reasonable. But if that was the whole story, then, why hasn't NASA announced a NET May date? It has now been more than two weeks since NASA said "we’ll provide an update soon on when we expect to launch the OFT-2 mission." ( https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/2021/03/04/nasa-and-boeing-evaluating-launch-date-for-orbital-flight-test-2/ ) They have not, and I believe it is because they can't.
At this point, everything would have to go exactly right to get inside the deadline. I'm betting that doesn't happen.

They have at least now got a provisional NASA launch approval pencilled in for sometime in May (before they were just saying that it would be at some unspecified time in the future).  They still have not published a hard date though: 
https://spaceflightnow.com/launch-schedule/  I will come back to this in a week or so to see if any further details have been clarified.  It is very hard to make an informed prediction when so much is unpublished.  Boeing badly need a win though, and will presumably be pressing hard.   From the current time, where no date has even been specified for the launch, I still see it as less likely than the current crowd consensus (15%). If the launch date starts slipping into June, then their window for a successful docking mission (which is a whole other battle) will be very tight to meet the 1 July deadline for this forecast.  If it goes beyond the second week of June, I'll need to start looking at timescales that comparable missions required.   Right now though (without so much as a launch date) I don't really have the time.

OFT-2 planned no earlier than May 2021 with exact date TBD. Has already been delayed twice but software has been approved. Delay from April seems reasonable given 2 other scheduled launches to ISS that month. The next scheduled ISS docking is MS-17 on June 9th.  Although delays are not uncommon it seems the vast majority of early stage hiccups have been addressed and there will likely be adequate time for launchpad issues to be addressed prior to the July 1 deadline.

Current "No Earlier Than"- date (NET): May 2021
If next mention of a NET date is on 23 June 2021 or later, it will be highly unlikely that any docking attempt can happen in time before 01 July 2021 as for the purpose of this question.
Average mission duration for Boe-OFT 2 will be seven to fourteen days, planned docking/undocking demonstration included.

The root causes of failures have to be analyzed. Redesign has to be approved by many disciplines, certified and tested. This developments require several loops. Then a full system test has to be done successfully again. The whole procedure may take several months until a year. Spacecraft design is a unique challenge for Boeing. A failure during the first space mission will have been created a huge damage of reputation for Boeing. Therefore risk aversion will cause very many additional activities to ensure success for first flight but these doings require additional time.

Once again I am forecasting with egg on my face, it makes it hard to see the screen, but I'll try. Starliner program has dealt with numerous issues delaying a launch.
From https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/category/boeing/
"NASA and Boeing are evaluating a new target launch date for the CST-100 Starliner’s Orbital Flight Test-2 (OFT-2) to the International Space Station after winter storms in Houston, and the recent replacement of avionics boxes, set the program back about two weeks.
...
"Previously, the launch was targeted for no earlier than April 2. "An important factor the teams are evaluating is the visiting vehicle schedule at the International Space Station, which already has a scheduled crewed Soyuz launch and NASA’s SpaceX Crew-2 mission in April. Based on the current traffic at the space station, NASA does not anticipate that OFT-2 can be accomplished later in April. NASA and Boeing are working to find the earliest possible launch date." The above indicates that the only window is early April so as to not collide with two other programs headed to the ISS. The article was published 2 weeks ago with no further update at the blog. Any launch in early April should be scheduled by now and none exists.
Thus the launch window may be pushed to May or June or later. I'll forecast this by fence sitting, clearly lots of boxes have been checked and things have been done, but getting launch clearance at both the ground and at the ISS seriously complicates timing.

Boeing seems very much in need of a win after the persistent issues with their air vehicles and SpaceX perpetually out-achieving Boeing. Most of the discussion about launch dates seems to have misattributed the SLS (moon) and OFT (orbital crew capsule) systems. OFT has already launched before and was pushed back in Mar due to ground hardware issues. Further, the main issue delaying the launch of OFT-2 is a packed April schedule of visiting vehicles at the space station. Granted all of this could be smoke and mirrors from NASA and Boeing to hide a bigger problem. However, given Boeing's need for a successful launch and NASA's desire to have another US company capable of carrying crew to LEO I suspect a launch will happen in the May-June timeframe. With the outside possibility of a launch been delayed and NASA's failure to immediately reschedule I would judge the probability as slightly better than 50%.  https://www.americaspace.com/2021/03/05/starliners-oft-2-launch-date-under-review-ahead-of-busy-april-at-space-station/

There are too many tests to confirm safety and reliability that would need to occur before this is approved.  Between COVID issues and Boeings commercial aircraft issues, it would be almost impossible to assign the resources and capital to make it happen this fast.
Boeing is slow at development, as opposed to SpaceX. I wouldn't expect a lot of action in the short term.

From Spaceflight Now, referenced below by @MmeLyons777
"Boeing’s second Orbital Flight Test, or OFT-2, mission will verify the Starliner spacecraft is ready to carry astronauts into orbit for the first time later this year. In a statement Feb. 17, Boeing and NASA said the launch of the OFT-2 mission has been rescheduled from March 25 to no earlier than April 2. The eight-day delay was caused by a power surge during final checkouts on the spacecraft at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida." Any launch on a specific day is a 50-50 proposition but the window on this question gives an open time of about 115 days which is generous.

Arguments are summed up pretty well. OFT-1 software issues have been resolved, and weather is less likely to be a factor in May. But, delays are still probable, and testing doesn't confirm it will work. I don't think this is a 1 in 100 chance of working, but I wouldn't be too optimistic until a launch date is at least set.

Not sure where the pessimism about this question is coming from. NASA is eager to have 2 American space companies to compete with the Russians (https://spacepolicyonline.com/news/busy-iss-schedule-texas-weather-impact-crew-2-oft-2-launch-dates/). Boeing has requalified the spacecraft's flight software (https://www.space.com/boeing-starliner-software-approved-oft-2-test-flight, https://starlinerupdates.com/boeing-completes-software-qualification-for-second-starliner-test-flight/) and installed new avionics (https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/category/boeing/). Power-on testing and checkouts have been completed. Soyuz and SpaceX missions are planned for April, but Starliner would be able to dock in May, with a 2-month window of error for the question. Looking at the NASA schedule, there would be no other obstacles to the mission before September (https://www.nasa.gov/launchschedule/).

The flight has slipped to April, giving about 3 months of margin to the end of July.  The first test flight failed to dock but was otherwise successful.  Boeing has learned from that mission and the same error is unlikely to happen again.  The possibility of technical issues or launch failures still exist, which discounts the probability of success.

Seems like too tight of a schedule and there's the risk of the test flight uncovering more issues or being delayed again. That said I would probably go a bit higher because I would say a 1 in 10 chance sounds about right, but I'm hedging toward the crowd as I haven't done much research.
Yes, we try to harder to spend money to get people off of this rock than spending this money to help USA's systemic issue of poverty.

The next test flight is looking more like May (date was no earlier than April 2 and has continued to slip due to weather/power issues in Houston).  Boeing is on the NASA schedule for a 'no later than September' launch for a Crew test flight, which will only happen if the OFT-2 is successful.  The first question is when will OFT-2 launch. It is currently not on the NASA schedule (https://www.nasa.gov/launchschedule/) and a new date has not been mentioned in the NASA blog (https://blogs.nasa.gov/commercialcrew/category/boeing/) and is currently being shown as May (https://spaceflightnow.com/launch-schedule/). Any additional slippage will push this into June (power issues, last minute technical issues, weather issues, other missions getting a higher priority). The mission is set to last 7 to 14 days. Without knowing the flight plans we don't know when the actual docking would occur. It is conceivable that even if successfully launched at the end of June, it may not dock right away. The second question is will the mission be successful. With all of the sunk cost that has been poured into Boeing without any real results yet (as compared to SpaceX), you have to believe that they are going to both scrutinize the OFT-2 mission and try to get it off the ground soon to save face with the amount of money they have spent on it.

Does seem improbable given the timeline, but not impossible given the motivation.1 or 2 in 100 seems a reasonable starting point, particularly given the criteria for a successful mission, in addition to getting on agenda.

Boeing does appear to be under pressure from its fatal problems with the 737 Max and its Starliner spacecraft both due to serious software failure issues. This has probably caused a diminished trust in Boeing’s capability in their haste to complete projects.
NASA would like to have two functioning commercial companies to produce re-usable spacecraft with Elon Musk’s SpaceX being the other one and reduce the dependence on the Russian systems.
Perhaps the competition is proving to be a disadvantage.
Also, there is a pile up of dates to allow travel to the ISS due to Soyuz and SpaceX that will delay the launch of the Boeing Starliner. There is no determined date at the moment.
I will therefore suggest that given NASA’s necessary risk averse nature, the date will slip beyond 1st July 2021.  https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210302-boeing-starliner-test-flight-postponed  https://spaceflightnow.com/2021/03/02/boeings-next-starliner-test-flight-delayed-after-spacex-crew-rotation/  https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2020/03/06/nasa-shows-its-lost-confidence-boeings-ability-police-its-own-work-starliner-space-capsule/  https://www.financialexpress.com/lifestyle/science/commercial-space-programme-nasa-boeing-targeting-april-for-cst-100-starliners-test-flight/2197059/  https://www.clickorlando.com/news/local/2021/03/05/nasa-shifts-next-astronaut-launch-with-spacex-boeing-starliner-test-flight-date-tbd/
When and if they announce a launch date before 1 July, I'll consider the odds that they'll be able to meet it.

NASA expressed concern "...with the rigor of Boeing’s verification processes" after a December 2020 Starliner flight test failure. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-space-exploration-boeing/boeings-botched-starliner-test-flirted-with-catastrophic-failure-nasa-panel-idUSKBN20106A) Competitor SpaceX has jumped ahead (of Boeing) with "Crew Dragon": https://observer.com/2021/02/boeing-starliner-behind-spacex-crew-dragon-iss-mission-nasa/ Boeing Starliner's Orbital Flight Test 2 (next test) has been pushed back to "later in April" or possibly "early May": https://www.space.com/boeing-2nd-starliner-test-flight-launch-delayed, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Orbital_Flight_Test_2 Will monitor progress but starting the forecast a little on the higher side, as it doesn't seem "impossible" (to me) that Boeing can complete a successful flight and dock by July.

https://spaceflightnow.com/2021/03/02/boeings-next-starliner-test-flight-delayed-after-spacex-crew-rotation/ Launch has currently been delayed twice, first to 2 April, and then last week it delayed again and the soonest it could possibly happen is sometime in May - but even with that broad window, they are still yet to pin down a date. I'll keep an open mind and update my forecast upwards if they do get around to announcing so much as a launch date (which is only the very first step), but until then a successful launch, orbital flight and ISS docking by the end of June is currently looking v unlikely IMO.
Boeing badly needs something to go right.  This won't be it.
